Common Concurrency Bugs

36. Common Concurrency Bugs#

In our examples introducing the need for mutual exclusion and enforcing ordering of thread events, we have already seen some examples of how things can go wrong without correct synchronization. In this chapter, we examine the three most common types of concurrency bugs: atomicity violations, order violations, and deadlocks. We will focus on deadlocks, since we have already seen the tools needed to address the other two types of bugs.

Our bug classifications, and real-world examples, are drawn from Lu et al.’s 2008 study of concurrency bugs [LPSZ08], which examined 105 randomly selected concurrency bugs drawn from four open-source applications (MySQL, Apache, Mozilla, and OpenOffice). The selected bugs included 31 deadlock bugs, and 74 non-deadlock bugs. We summarize the breakdown of the bugs in the study in Table 36.1.

Table 36.1 Concurrency Bug Breakdown (3 bugs are counted as both atomicity violation and order violation)#

Bug Category

Bug Count

Deadlock

31

Atomicity Violation

51

Order Violation

24

Other

2

 
## Atomicity Violations
